captions.text:
Our planet is surrounded by a wispy-thin layer
of gas that keeps us warm and allows weather

to happen and basically makes all of life
on Earth possible. Except... that precious

atmosphere of ours is actually leaking, every
second, into outer space.

Luckily, it's a really slow leak, since for
any object--be it a molecule of gas, a rocket,

or a cat -- to break the tether of Earth's
gravity and escape, it has to hightail it
out of here at 34 times the speed of sound.

It takes the energy of a metric tonne of TNT
to boost a person to that speed, and less

energy for lighter objects: 1/10th of that
for a cat, for example. Barring a large asteroid

impact that can eject large swaths of atmosphere
into space, the only gases that regularly

escape Earth's atmosphere today are Hydrogen
and Helium - the lightest elements in the
universe.

There are a few ways hydrogen and helium molecules
can wind up on a one-way mission to space.

Some, near the top of the atmosphere simply
get enough energy from the sun's heat to escape.

Others are high-energy charged particles that
would usually be stopped from escaping by

the Earth's magnetic field. Occasionally,
though, these speedy electron-lacking particles

crash into a neutral molecule with enough
force to knock loose--and steal--one of its

electrons. Now neutral itself, the speeding
particle is free of the earth's magnetic field,

and if the collision happens to set it on
a course for the stars, that's where it goes.

Finally, some of Earth's magnetic field lines
are weakened and pushed away from the earth

by the solar wind, a violent stream of plasma
emanating from our sun. Charged particles

guided by these magnetic fields can simply
fly off the weak ends like sparks off a live
wire.

But if our planet didn't have a magnetic field
at all, things could be a lot worse. Mars,

for example, has no protective magnetic field,
and so what little atmosphere it has is constantly

buffeted and ripped away by the solar wind.
Even with its protective bubble, Earth is

losing enough hydrogen to fill a meter-wide
balloon every second. No need to worry - it'll

take a few billion years before we lose all
of our hydrogen this way, but maybe sometime

in the distant future, someone will look at
Earth and ask, just as we do of Mars now:
Was there ever life on this chunk of rock?

venus wasn't even turned to hell. Venus was always like that. And if

comments.author: EzioAuditore949

comments.text:
+EzioAuditore949 You failed to mention that Venus is 900 degrees because of 
the CO2 (Mercury doesn't even get 900 degrees and it's closer to the sun 
and Mercury gets really cold at night while Venus's temps are largely 
unaffected by night). The standard for terrestrial planets is to be loaded 
with CO2 from volcanic outgassing (the amount of atmosphere is based on the 
geologic capacity to do volcanic activity, thus bigger is better). Venus 
has the thick atmosphere because of the lack of oceans and Earth would 
probably be the same way if our oceans boiled away. Currently our oceans 
absorb CO2 and bind it in rocks, where it must be dragged to a subduction 
zone to be released again. Mars was too small to maintain a magnetosphere 
and the solar wind stripped it's atmosphere down to the point where the air 
pressure does not allow liquid water to exist except in the lowest of 
elevations. While Venus simply spins too slow to make a magnetosphere but 
it has so much atmosphere that any losses would have been insignificant. 

The greenhouse science is true, but it isn't necessarily an end of world 
scenario and life goes on, as the world used to be warm enough for hickory 
forests on greenland, palms in Alaska, deciduous forests in Antarctica (and 
this is only in the several million years before the ice age climate 
started, the continent positions weren't all that far from where they are 
today). Earth can be warmer. Now, if it does happen fast, there could be 
extinctions and perhaps civilization may collapse, but life will go on.

comments.text:
What do you think is the most exciting aspect of Earth’s atmosphere? Just 
think about it for a second.What do you know about the atmosphere, search 
your brain for something that’ll knock your socks off…are you coming up 
empty? It’s not exactly a subject that sends most people jumping with 
enthusiasm despite the fact that it’s vital for life and responsible for 
weather, which alone is pretty rad, right? I think what makes an atmosphere 
truly exciting is all in the way you think about it.

Watch this video by +MinutePhysics and read more about why our atmosphere 
is so awesome at Science Wonderful: 
http://sciencewonderful.blog.com/archives/4/

Then answer the question, what do you think is the most exciting thing 
about our atmosphere?!﻿

comments.author: Павел Жданов

comments.text:
Yes, but I would guess the probability of that happening would be immensely 
slim. If I approximate the entire planet of venus as a point, I can 
calculate how thin of an trajectory an atom has to have in order to reach 
earth (assuming the atom will travel in a straight line, which is will not, 
so the real number is actually even smaller). Anyway if venus is 24 million 
miles away at it's closest approach, and earth is about 10000 miles across, 
do some quick trig on my calculator and I get that that means they must 
from a sliver no more than 0.02 degrees thick in order to hit the earth. 
Again it's gross approximation, I'm doing this problem in only 
2-dimensions, when I really should be doing three, and I'm also assuming 
the atoms travel in completely straight lines and that venus is just an 
infinitely small point, but regardless it should give you an idea of how 
few atoms would make it to the Earth.

comments.text:
The video fails to mention that the rate of H2 loss will increase in the 
future due to the sun's steadily increasing luminosity. In about 1 billion 
years, the increased solar flux will cause a runaway greenhouse that will 
cause the oceans to evaporate away.
But don't worry. Even before that happens (600-800 million years from now), 
lowering CO2 levels also due to increased solar luminosity will kill all 
plant life on earth, thereby killing all animals, including humans' 
descendents.﻿

comments.text:
+Douglas Kalles My problem isn't even stealing, it's the government saying 
"ooh, we'll take care of that nasty plutonium, don't want anyone stealing 
it, we'll keep in in a secret place".
A *single* pressurised water reactor creates enough plutonium and related 
nuclear material for about 25 Nagasaki sized bombs *every year*.
You pretty much have to *trust* that government not to make any nukes from 
it, it's a nightmare keeping track of all the plutonium and other materials 
that are used for nuclear bombs.

This is a problem, you end up with a two-tier international energy plan, 
one for trusted countries and another for untrusted. And all the untrusted 
countries get pissy that they aren't trusted and take offence at accusation 
they'd use it to make nuclear weapons.

This has happened REPEATEDLY. India and Pakistan got their nuclear weapons 
by initially totally committing to "peaceful use of nuclear power" and 
bought nuclear industry equipment from Germany... they developed a bomb in 
secret, tested it and voila. It's happened so many other times.

And we tolerate this for the time being as they are not used... but if they 
ever are...
comments.author: Treblaine

We have some evidence that shows that maybe there was multi-cellular life 
on Mars in prehistoric times.  There is ice beneath the surface of mars, 
showing there is water (which is necessary for life), and some surface 
samples showed that the planet and it's atmosphere used to be able to 
sustain life.  Whether or not life evolved there is uncertain.  Also, 
nowadays, we found single-celled bacteria on a rover on Mars, which is 
life.  Just not  the green, big-headed, space-faring empire many science 
fiction movies predicted.

comments.text:
Hydrogen as a component of water is necessary for life, but the loss of 
*pure* hydrogen and helium is *not* really all too concerning. Just putting 
some oxygen and hydrogen in a tank won't magically cause rain to start 
falling. :P

Both poisonous and necessary are kind of misleading. "Non-vital" would be a 
more accurate term, I believe.

comments.text:
Semantics (I didn't want to say 'tangled' as you did). But it's called 
monatomic molecule. Molecules kind of generalize the atoms. If you have an 
atom, you have a monatomic molecule. If you have two atoms tangled 
together, you have a diatomic molecule... and so on. This nomenclature is 
very common in the studies of gas dynamics.
comments.author: John Rambo

Because helium is not a molecular element, a molecule is a compound made of

for those compounds. Helium is measured in a unit called "Mol(s)"
